change.title: MINISTRY OF ENERGY, MINES AND PETROLEUM RESOURCES ACT

change.changenote: Section 1(1) BEFORE amended by 2002-26-10, effective June 20, 2003 (BC Reg 232/2003).

subsection.subsectiontext: There is to be a ministry of the public service called the Ministry of Energy, Mines and Petroleum Resources.

Section 8.3 (1) BEFORE amended by 2023-10-595, effective March 30, 2023 (Royal Assent).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: At an oral hearing, the investigator may make orders or give directions that he or she considers necessary for the maintenance of order at the hearing, and, if any person disobeys or fails to comply with any order or direction, the investigator may call on the assistance of any peace officer to enforce the order or direction.

change.changenote: Section 12.1 was enacted by 2018-47-148, effective February 5, 2021 (BC Reg 11/2021).
Section 13 BEFORE re-enacted by 2002-26-11, effective June 20, 2003 (BC Reg 232/2003).

section.sectiontext: With the approval of the Lieutenant Governor in Council, the minister may authorize loans, guarantees, investments, grants and the expenditure of money for the design, construction, reconstruction and repair of trails, roads, bridges, rails, utilities and other works to facilitate exploration and development of energy, mineral and petroleum resources in British Columbia.

change.changenote: Section 13.1 was enacted by 2002-26-11, effective June 20, 2003 (BC Reg 232/2003).
Section 14 BEFORE repealed by 2022-14-17, effective June 2, 2022 (Royal Assent).

bcl:definition.bcl:text: assay means the quantification of an element in a sample of rock, mineral, ore or metallurgical product;
assayer means a person who performs an assay;
board means the board of examiners appointed under section 20;
certificate means a certificate of qualification as an assayer granted under section 16, 17 or 21 (5);
certified assayer means a person holding a certificate.

change.changenote: Section 15 BEFORE repealed by 2022-14-17, effective June 2, 2022 (Royal Assent).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Twice each year, or more frequently as the minister directs, the board must conduct examinations in the practice of assaying and in other related subjects that the minister directs.
A candidate for an examination must pay the prescribed fee before being examined.

change.changenote: Section 16 BEFORE repealed by 2022-14-17, effective June 2, 2022 (Royal Assent).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister must grant a certificate to a person who passes the examination required by section 15.
A certificate of efficiency granted under a former enactment, and not revoked or suspended, is deemed a certificate under this Act.

change.changenote: Section 17 BEFORE repealed by 2022-14-17, effective June 2, 2022 (Royal Assent).

bcl:section.bcl:text: The minister may grant a certificate without examination to a person who, on application and payment of the prescribed fee, satisfies the board

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that the person has practical experience in chemical analysis and assaying, and has successfully completed courses in those subjects at a school recognized by the board, and
that the practical experience, courses and examinations at the school are adequate to ensure accurate assaying.

change.changenote: Section 18 BEFORE repealed by 2022-14-17, effective June 2, 2022 (Royal Assent).

bcl:section.bcl:text: A certificate granted under section 16 or 17 is evidence that the person named in it is qualified to perform assays.

change.changenote: Section 19 BEFORE repealed by 2022-14-17, effective June 2, 2022 (Royal Assent).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Unless a person holds a certificate granted under this Act, the person must not do any of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by advertisement or otherwise, offer the person's services as a certified assayer;
ask or receive payment for performing an assay, not performed under the supervision of a certified assayer;
give a written statement of the result of an assay performed by the person.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who contravenes this section commits an offence.
This section does not apply to a person

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: who holds a certificate of efficiency granted under an earlier enactment on assayers, or
who practised as an assayer immediately before September 1, 1979, so long as the person was granted a certificate within one year after that date.

change.changenote: Section 20 BEFORE repealed by 2022-14-17, effective June 2, 2022 (Royal Assent).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister must appoint a board of examiners consisting of a chair and 2 other persons, each of whom the minister believes has the qualifications to act as an examiner under section 15.
A board member is appointed during the pleasure of the minister but for a term not exceeding 3 years.
A board member must be reimbursed for reasonable travelling and out of pocket expenses necessarily incurred in discharging duties, and in addition may be paid remuneration determined by the minister.

change.changenote: Section 21 BEFORE repealed by 2022-14-17, effective June 2, 2022 (Royal Assent).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A candidate who fails an examination or is refused examination by the board may appeal to the minister.
The candidate must serve the minister and the board with a notice of appeal within 30 days after the decision or refusal.
The minister must hear the appeal within 60 days after receiving the notice of appeal and must make the decision known to the candidate within 15 days after the hearing.
The candidate and the board are entitled to attend and be represented at the hearing before the minister.
On hearing the appeal the minister may do any of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: order the board to mark the examination again;
order the board to examine or reexamine the candidate;

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister's decision on the appeal is final and not subject to review.

change.changenote: Section 22 BEFORE repealed by 2000-23-43, effective March 31, 2002.

subsection.subsectiontext: The minister must submit to the Lieutenant Governor in Council an annual report on the work performed by the ministry.
The report must be laid before the Legislative Assembly if it is in session, or, if it is not in session, within 15 days after the commencement of the next session.
